Title: the clean room infiltration

Penny: Hey, how are things going with your parents?
You know what? That was almost on topic. I’m gonna say good job, Sheldon.
Me, too.
So, Dr. Koothrappali, long flight?
Oh, that’s rough.
Oh, great. Everything’s good.
Yes, we did.
You’re just gonna leave him here?
So, if you don’t mind me asking, do you think you might start dating again?
No, but if things don’t work out with me and Leonard, I’ll give you a call. Wait. How much do you talk about Star Trek?
Like what?
Sorry. She’s taken, too.
Certainly doesn’t feel like it, does it?
Oh, I guess that’s where Raj gets it from.
Hey, you know, Raj is dating a doctor who works a lot. Him and his mom have a type. You, you got to laugh at that, right? No? All right.
It’s kind of boring. Although it did get exciting for a minute when Amy inhaled a wool ball. How much longer do you think you’ll be?
Honey, it’s Christmas Eve. Who even knows you’re in there?
So erase them and walk out.
Oh, Sheldon, we didn’t bring any.
Of course it is.
Raj: Not great. They hired divorce attorneys.
Anyway, Dad’s gonna be here in town, so I won’t be able to do Christmas dinner this year.
That would be nice.
Amy, good luck getting these guys excited about a dinner with a theme. I gave up when no one cared about my Tom Hanks-giving.
You guys suck.
Can we please talk about anything else?
Dad.
There’s been a problem with an experiment. A bird got into the clean room.
Uh, no. You had a long flight. You stay here and relax.
Yup. Bye.
Hey, what’s going on?
Should have put it in the bag first.
Hey.
Okay.
Actually.

All I’m gonna say is you guys need to stop this right now. It. it’s bad enough that my parents are fighting, now I have to hear the two of you? And who cares who’s smarter? If it’s Leonard or me or, you know, it’s Christmas, let’s say it’s Howard.
No, you’re the one who let him in.
Come on.
Uh, you have to take the pin out.
What did you do?
Dude, it’s not breathing.
What do you mean, not again?
I’ll do it.
Don’t blow too hard. If you pop him, I will vomit.
It’s a Christmas miracle.
Someone should really close that loading door.
Well, that’s that. The room’s compromised. They’ll have to change all the filters, probably shut it down for weeks.
Yeah, just leave me out of it. You know if they come here and see crap everywhere, they’re just gonna blame the Indian guy.
Mmm. Amy, that pudding was delicious.
If you people think this is better than Tom Hanks-giving, you’re all crazy.
Sheldon: You know, speaking of attorneys, if I ever needed a lawyer, I would not hire She-Hulk.
Yes, but she’s the only monster at the firm. Between you, me and the wall, I think she’s an affirmative action hire.
Ugh. English pudding. You get yourself all excited for pudding, and here comes a cake with raisins in it. I’m not going.
Why do you hate me?
Well, you call it love, but it has a lot of raisins in it.
Yeah, I appreciate the ride.
Because in the last ten minutes, Santa came to town, kissed Mommy and ran Grandma over with a reindeer. I had a drunk uncle who did all those things. Nobody sings songs about him.
My uncle was accused of that, too. It turned out to be legal in Oklahoma.
Oh, we’re not exchanging gifts.

Why should I? She knows that I don’t like Christmas, and yet, every year, she forces me to celebrate it. Not only am I going to this foolish dinner against my will, at the Christmas tree lot, there was mistletoe, and she kissed me under it in public. Like we were the stars of a Tijuana sex show.
Yes, and she’s not taking my feelings into account at all. Maybe it’s time I teach her a lesson.
Hmm. It’d have to be something heinous, something that makes her as miserable as she’s making me. Oh, I’ve got it. This is good.
I’m going to buy her a present.
With gift-giving, there’s an implied social contract. If I show up tonight with a present, and she doesn’t have one for me, she’ll feel terrible.
Yes. Maybe she’ll feel so guilty, she’ll never make me celebrate the holidays again.
That’s right. So stay on my good side, or I’ll get you a little something, too.
No, it’s not good enough. It has to be perfect.

Hmm. Let’s see, what do I know about Amy? She loves medieval literature, Chaucer’s her favourite. And her eyes sparkle when she watches old French movies. I enjoy how harp music causes her fingers to dance as if she’s playing along.
I do. Now, let’s find the kind of gift that makes her feel small and worthless.
Correct.
There’s an argument for that. But I want to make sure.
If you like raisins.
Oh. Oh, in that case, it was pretty good.
Uh, what do you say we exchange gifts?
Yeah, I do. Which is why I got Amy this.
Oh, not just something, no. It’s from the heart, it’s holiday-themed, and I swallowed the gift receipt so you cannot return it.
Of course it is. It’s the perfect gift. How are you feeling right now? Guilty? Sad? Wishing you were Jewish?

Oh, really? Well, how about now? (On recording) Happy holidays to my dear Amy. I hope you treasure this as much as I treasure you. (Not on recording) And you got me nothing. Christmas is ruined. Let’s never speak of it again. Well, this was fun.
But what about our agreement?
Cookies?
They’re perfect. It tastes like her hugs.
I can’t believe this. You’re happy, I’m happy. Well, maybe a holiday that’s all about giving isn’t so… Get your hand out of that box.
Amy: If you’re not up to hosting Christmas dinner, I’m happy to do it. You can even bring your father.
I’ve always wanted to do a traditional Victorian Christmas. Parlour games, goose and figgy pudding.
I don’t hate you. I love you.
Okay, let’s get this Victorian party started. I’ve done some research about some traditional parlour games we can play.
Well, there’s a fun one called Ball of Wool. You take a ball of wool, and you put it right in the centre of the table. Then people sit on opposite sides of the table and try to blow the wool off.
Look at you on Santa’s lap. That’s so sweet.
Actually, I did get you something.
Well, you got me something. Here.
They’re your Meemaw’s Christmas cookies. I called and got the recipe.
Okay. The next game is called Hot Boiled Beans.
One person is sent out of the room while the others hide a small item. Then they invite the first person back by saying hot boiled beans and bacon for supper, hurry up before it gets cold.
Howard: Yeah, she works at a law firm in New York.
I agree.
We should get going to Amy’s.
I know. If we were still single, we’d be tripping over all that booty.
How the hell did a pigeon get in here?
I thought you did.
You mean ’cause this room isn’t supposed to have dust in it, and we just let in a flying crap machine?
And tell them that we compromised all the equipment? Let’s just get it out of here before anyone knows.
Well, what if we turn off all the lights except for one, and it’ll come to it.
Don’t yell at me. You’re not gonna get any good ideas out of me if you’re yelling.
Great, we’re turning on each other. That’s just what the bird wants us to do.
Okay, here’s the plan. I’m gonna put the food in the bag, and when he lands in the bag to eat it, we close it up.
It’s all I could find. It’ll work.
Okay, well, what’s your plan?
And admit that we contaminated the clean room?
Why do you keep assuming it was me?
Like when?
Again, it looked like my car, and the baby didn’t even cry until his mother punched me with her keys.
Well, what if you said it without sounding so condescending?
You know what I think your problem is? You’re jealous because you and I used to be best friends until Koothrappali came along.
Stay out of this.
You know, maybe I’m best friends with Raj because he doesn’t think he’s smarter than me.
I said, stay out of it.
Well, if you’re so smart, you get the bird out.
How do you know it wasn’t Leonard?
Are you sure a dummy like me can handle something as complicated as a blanket?
Yeah, I do.
Okay. One, two, three.
On three. One, two, three.
It was an accident. Oh, my God. Oh, my God.
Uh, maybe it’s just stunned.
Oh, no. I killed it. Oh, not again.
When I was ten, I was playing in my backyard and sat on a blue jay. I mean, I tried to bring it back to life with electricity, but it just caught on fire. The worst part was it smelled delicious.
Great. Do it.
No. I need to do it. This is on me.
I am tasting a lot of Slim Jim.
Oh, he blinked his eyes. He’s alive.
I might argue a Hanukkah miracle, but I’ll take it. Come on, little guy, let’s get you outside. Get the curtain.
You were right. Go ahead, call Building Services. Tell them it was my fault.
Can’t do what?
We can’t do that.
It smelled too much like blue jay.
Bernadette: I think a Victorian Christmas sounds nice.
Maybe you’d like it more if you thought of Santa as a superhero and his power is bringing joy to children.
Okay, new subject. Let’s talk about presents. What did you get Amy?
Come on, Sheldon, you have to get her something.
She’s just excited about the holidays.
Yeah, you’re gonna have to walk me through that.
So your evil plot here is to buy your girlfriend a present?
I think the nicest gifts I’ve got from Howie show how well he knows me.
Wow, you really do love her.
You feeling okay? You hardly touched your goose.
Leonard: Why not?
You know the best part of working in the clean room? No allergies. Check it out. Oh, that, that, that’s a lot of oxygen.

Can you believe there was a time when we would have needed an array of giant Cherenkov telescopes to detect cosmic particles? And here we are building our own multi-wire detector like a couple of badasses.
Ladies do love a man dressed like a kitchen garbage bag. Oh, no.
You shut the loading doors, right?
Do you know what a disaster this is?
What do we do? Should we call someone?
Okay, how do we catch it?
It’s not a moth.
Okay, so if I remain calm, I’ll get more gems like turn off the lights?
A Slim Jim?
Sure. If the pigeon’s stoned or a trucker.
I told you my plan. Let’s call Building Services and get help.
No, admit that you contaminated the clean room.
Because you do this kind of thing all the time, and then you try to cover it up.
What about when you flipped the Mars Rover, or lost Koothrappali’s dog, or almost drove off with that baby?
Fine, put the Slim Jim in the garbage bag.
I can try, but your plan has the words garbage bag and Slim Jim in it.
Oh. Genius here wants to catch a bird with a garbage bag and a Slim Jim.
And you found somebody you could push around?
No, no, no. No, Raj, go ahead, say what you were gonna say.
Okay. On the count of three, I’ll shoot the fire extinguisher and get him airborne. Howard, you wave the blanket and guide him towards the exit. Raj, you hold open the curtain so he can fly out.
Do you want the fire extinguisher?
Great. Here you go.
You miss the blanket now, don’t you?
Relax, it wasn’t your fault.
Uh, guys, I found an article here that says you can do CPR on birds.
I’m not doing it. You killed him, you do it.
Okay. Mouth over beak and light chest compressions.
Anything?
Wait, wait, his wing moved.
No, we’re both to blame. You know, let me take the heat on this one.
I don’t know. There’s still a bird in here. We are gonna get in a ton of trouble.
No, our names are on the sign-in sheet.
I can’t do that.
She says take our names off the sign-in sheet and leave.
Yeah.
I thought you hate giving gifts.
Dr Koothrappali: Not at all. Did you know that when you fly transcontinental without your wife, you don’t pray for the plane to crash?
Forgive me. How are you and Leonard?
Let me tell you a story.
Sorry. I’m sure you won’t grow to hate each other.
Relax. Easy for you to say. Your mother isn’t cleaning out your bank account. Forty years, the woman never cleaned a thing.
It’s much too soon for that. Why? Do you know someone?
You know, my wife used to throw theme parties like this all the time.
Well, he and his mother spent a lot of time together when he was young. I was always working.
Can I help you clean up?
Raj (on phone): Hey, Leonard. What’s up? What? How did that happen? Yeah, okay. I’ll be there as soon as I can. Sorry. I have to run to the university.
Bernadette (singing): Here comes Santa Claus, here comes Santa Claus, right down Santa Claus Lane. Vixen and Blitzen and all his reindeer pulling on the reins.
Bells are ringing, children singing, all is merry and bright. So hang your stockings and say your prayers ’cause Santa Claus is coming tonight. Why’d you turn it off?
Santa: All right, let me see if I’ve got this straight. A picture of you on my lap is a way to punish your girlfriend for making you celebrate Christmas?
Santa thinks dating you may be punishment enough.
Leonard (on phone): Hey. I’m sorry, we’re still here. Is everything okay?
Leonard, Howard and Raj (singing): Jingle bells, jingle bells, jingle all the way. Oh, what fun it is to ride in a one-horse open sleigh, hey.

Should have put it in the bag first.

It’s much too soon for that. Why? Do you know someone?

And you found somebody you could push around?
You know, maybe I’m best friends with Raj because he doesn’t think he’s smarter than me.
I said, stay out of it.
No, no, no. No, Raj, go ahead, say what you were gonna say.

There’s an argument for that. But I want to make sure.

Hey. I’m sorry, we’re still here. Is everything okay?

I don’t know. There’s still a bird in here. We are gonna get in a ton of trouble.
